entry.title: Premature Optimization Is the Root of All Evil
entry.content: “Premature optimization is the root of all evil.” – Donald Knuth

entry.title: Bad Behavior Arises When You Abstract People Away From the Consequences of Their Actions
entry.content: “Bad behavior arises when you abstract people away from the consequences of their actions.” – Jez Humble

entry.title: User Stories Are Just Options, Not Commitment
entry.content: “User stories are just options, not commitment.” – Gojko Adzic

entry.title: Unless Scope Is Flexible, Organisations Do Not Benefit From Agile
entry.content: “Unless scope is flexible, organisations do not benefit from agile.” – Gojko Adzic

entry.title: Unit Testing Won’t Help You Write Good Code
entry.content: “Unit testing won’t help you write good code.” – Chad Okere

entry.title: The Only Best Practice You Should Be Using All the Time Is Use Your Brain
entry.content: “The only “best practice” you should be using all the time is Use Your Brain.” – Steven Robbins

entry.title: Most Comments in Code Are in Fact a Pernicious Form of Code Duplication.
entry.content: “Most comments in code are in fact a pernicious form of code duplication.” – Ed Guiness

entry.title: If It Hurts, Do It More Frequently, and Bring the Pain Forward
entry.content: “If it hurts, do it more frequently, and bring the pain forward.” – Jez Humble

entry.title: Being Able to Write a Bloom Filter in Erlang, or Write Multi-threaded C in Your Sleep Is Insufficient. None of That Matters if No One Wants to Work With You.
entry.content: “Being able to write a Bloom Filter in Erlang, or write multi-threaded C in your sleep is insufficient. None of that matters if no one wants to work with you.” – John Allspaw

entry.title: The First 90 Percent of the Code Accounts for the First 90 Percent of the Development Time. The Remaining 10 Percent of the Code Accounts for the Other 90 Percent of the Development Time.
entry.content: “The first 90 percent of the code accounts for the first 90 percent of the development time. The remaining 10 percent of the code accounts for the other 90 percent of the development time.” – Tom Cargill – Ninety-ninety rule

entry.title: Given Enough Eyeballs, All Bugs Are Shallow.
entry.content: “Given enough eyeballs, all bugs are shallow.” – Linus Torvalds – Linus’s Law

entry.title: A Bad Website Is Like a Grumpy Salesperson.
entry.content: “Any simple problem can be made insoluble if enough meetings are held to discuss it.” – Mitchell’s Law of Committees

entry.title: There Is No End to What Can Be Accomplished if You Don’t Care Who Gets the Credit.
entry.content: “There is no end to what can be accomplished if you don’t care who gets the credit.” – Art Rennison

entry.title: You're Bound to Be Unhappy if You Optimize Everything.
entry.content: “You’re bound to be unhappy if you optimize everything.” – Donald Knuth

entry.title: The Trouble With Programmers Is That You Can Never Tell What a Programmer Is Doing Until It's Too Late.
entry.content: “The trouble with programmers is that you can never tell what a programmer is doing until it’s too late.” – Seymour Cray

entry.title: Work Expands So as to Fill the Time Available for Its Completion.
entry.content: “Work expands so as to fill the time available for its completion.” – Parkinson’s Law

entry.title: Crash Programs Fail Because They Are Based on the Theory That, With Nine Women Pregnant, You Can Get a Baby a Month.
entry.content: “Crash programs fail because they are based on the theory that, with nine women pregnant, you can get a baby a month.” – Wernher von Braun

entry.title: When the Final Design Seems Too Simple for the Amount of Work You've Put in, Then You Know You're Done.
entry.content: “When the final design seems too simple for the amount of work you’ve put in, then you know you’re done.” – Brady Clark

entry.title: When in Doubt, Leave It Out.
entry.content: “When in doubt, leave it out.” — Joshua Bloch

entry.title: This Is Where Programming Ends, and the Real Detective Work Begins.
entry.content: “This is where programming ends, and the real detective work begins.” – Phillip Winter
